did.abstract: The Morris Loeb Scrapbook is a collection of newspaper tributes and obituaries compiled shortly after the death of Dr. Morris Loeb, a chemist and former NYU Chemistry Department Chair (1891-1906), in October 1912.

bioghist.head: Biography
bioghist.p: Morris Loeb was born in Cincinnati, Ohio in 1863 to banker Solomon Loeb and his wife Betty. Loeb was educated at Harvard University (1879-1883) and earned his Ph.D. in Berlin in 1887. In 1888, Loeb assisted his former Harvard professor Dr. Wolcott Gibbs, and the following year became a Docent in Chemistry at Clark University. In 1891, at the age of 28, he was appointed Chair of Chemistry at the University of the City of New York (renamed New York University in 1896) where he developed the Chemistry Department and was involved in the construction of the Havemeyer Chemical Laboratory in University Heights. In 1906, Loeb left NYU to continue his research at a private laboratory at the Chemists’ Club, and eventually became that organization's president. Morris Loeb’s scientific accomplishments included calculating the ionic velocity of silver, developing new methods for calculating molecular weights, and designing an improved cathode for measuring electric currents. Loeb was also a philanthropist, contributing to institutions such as the Hebrew Technical Institute for Boys, the Jewish Agricultural and Industrial Aid Society, the Chemists’ Club, and Harvard University. Morris Loeb died on October 8, 1912 after suffering from typhoid, leaving his wife Edna Kuhn Loeb and no children.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This collection consists of one scrapbook, comprised of approximately 78 leaves. The contents of the scrapbook are primarily obituaries of Morris Loeb, printed in New York City-area newspapers shortly after his death in 1912.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The scrapbook is unbound and housed in one legal-sized folder. The leaves remain in the order in which they were received.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials at the New York University Archives
relatedmaterial.p: Researchers should consult the Robert Hall Notebook, MC 62, as Robert Hall was Morris Loeb's immediate predecessor as Chair of Chemistry at New York University. They might also consult the Faculty Publications, RG 1.0, particularly The Scientific Work of Morris Loeb (Richards, Theodore W., ed., 1913).
